bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 7, 1941

div1.p: Kean enjoyed the “Hygeia” article and the reproduction of Cornwell's painting, of which he requests copies. He discusses some of the men on leave during the Yellow Fever Board experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 7, 1941

opener.dateline: 2804 N St. Washington, D. C. Oct.7 1941

div1.p:
Believe it or not, the temperature for the last
four days has had an average Max. of 92°F and
it is in the 90s this, the 5th day, while I write, but I
have sworn by the Great Horn Spoon, (which is a yale
oath which I acquired from my brothers-in-law) that I
will write to you today- Mrs. Kean and I are concern-
ed that you should have troubled yourself about the
photo of my picture in Cuba- She says that the copy
you send is just as good as the original and she
is entirely satisfied with it. And she has no doubt
that you have already returned the original and
that I will come across it some day- Of this she
is the more confident since I found in a drawer
of my desk some unopened letters, one of them to
her, with postmarks of Sept. 1 & 2- I think they were
stuck in there when my desk was being “straightened
up by some friendly but ill-advised hand, while I was
sick about labor day- There was no letter from you
in them however- How you can carry on your Rheumatism
Review and all the other things you do is a source
of wonder and admiration to me- Yesterday came
the Hygeia with your excellent article and the colored
reproduction of Cornwell's painting- It makes a very
AC
K
2
striking picture and I feel much indebted, primarily to you,
and then to Mr. Kellogg and the artist, that I should be
included in it- I am sure that Gen. Truby feels the
same way- I think you will bear witness that it was
not due to any promptings on our part- As I wrote
Truby recently I find from my diary that the Starks
left Cuba on leave on Sept. 3 on the transport Roulingo
(which Gen Lee called the Rollings from the way she rolled)
He went on this same trip on leave also- The Starks re-
turned on Oct. 27th and were so away during a very impor-
tant part of the Episode-

Col. Havard went on leave Nov. 14 and I took his office
until his return on January 8, 1901-

Somehow Stark is not particularly associated in my mind
with the activities of the Y. F. Board- He was a very
clever and amusing companion and much interested
in his professional work, especially on the Surgical side-
He was a great talker and I think that Reed, tho. he
was fond of Stark did not talk to him much of the
things that he wanted to keep quiet- Truby will however
know more about this than I do-

I am so much pleased at the pleasure that you found
in Trubys narrative- It was my experience and Gen.
Ireland's too that where we began it we did not
want to put it down- When I write to him I will
tell him what you say as it will give him great
pleasure- To go back to Hygeia are they going to make you
3
a bunch of reprints?

I think they ought to do so without charge, for the
poor editing they did in scattering it, in little dabs,
all through the number- It is worse than the Saturday
Evening Post- Of course the Post has to count on its advertis-
ing to carry it, but a magazine gotten out by the A. M. A.
ought to be above that, just as it should be above having
a nude female, rubbing her behind with a fake cure
for steatopygia, on the front cover- It lacks dignity painfully.
If, as I understood from the copy of one of your letters to
Mr Kellogg, you are going to get a large lot of colored
reproductions of the picture I would be very much pleased
to have a few for family distribution - not the twenty
or more that you mention but half that number - 8 or 10-
I will see that General Ireland gets his copy of the
Kodak snapshot of us together and returns it to you with
his autograph- Perhaps it would be better to have
him do this the next time he drops in and
return them both together-

I have been going through my old papers from time to
time lalety and discarding those that can have no future
value- I shall think of you if I find any that
refer to the y. f. Episode or any other that may be
of possible interest to you- I read last night a
letter from Dr. Juan Guiteras, written after the second
intervention, ice which he shows the difficulties of
establishing a two-party government in Cuba, which

I found of interest, as showing his philosophical mind
and also for the find, and I think well deserved,
compliment which he pays to the group of Americans
mainly army officers, who ran the two governments
of Intervention- The only scandal that I remember
involved a postal official who came down to
show the Cubans how to run their post offices- Gen-
Wood had him Fried and sent to the Penitentiary,
thereby incurring the wrath of the Senator from Ohio
whose appointe'e he was- When the time came
for Gen. Wood to have the promotion that was due
him this Senator held it up- It was only by the
valiant defence of the Sec'y of War, Mr Elihu Root,
that Gen. Wood who was then in the Philippines
won out. I do not know that I have ever
thanked you for the Proceedings of the Mayo
clinic which come to me every week and
which I read with much interest- It is pleasant
for me to get these glympses of where and how
far the Ulhaus of Science are scouting-

Cant you arrange to send us down a chunk
of cold air from Medicine Hot, or where ever
it is that blizzards are made up your way-
